newsitem.title: UK: Mark hugs mild gains on crosses in late Europe.
newsitem.headline: Mark hugs mild gains on crosses in late Europe.

text.p: The mark ended the European session clutching mild gains on most crosses, though narrow ranges held as players shrugged off new Franco-German vows that EMU would go ahead on time with the criteria fulfilled.

"The timetable will be respected. We have no doubt whatever on these points," French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis said after a bilateral economic summit in Lyon, echoing assurances by Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer.
But with the market still fearful of EMU delay, its concerns were highlighted by leading German economist Herbert Hax, who repeated his view that monetary union should be postponed.
"It is necessary to act taking into account the possibility the parameters for the euro might not be met," Hax, one of Germany's "wise men" advisers, told Italian radio.
"This doesn't mean relaxing the parameters but rather putting off the start of European Union for a year," he said.
The proposed stability council was also discussed at Lyon, with German Finance Minister Theo Waigel saying he would approve of an informal body.
Tietmeyer said the council would not control, supervise or be a counterweight to the European Central Bank.
Analysts said few surprises had emerged from Lyon.
"Very little has come out at all. As expected, there was the commitment to EMU on time," said Gwyn Hacche, senior European economist at HSBC James Capel.

"We need to see more evidence on recovery coming through, particularly in Germany," he said. "When markets switch from ultra-gloom over the German economy to believing more in recovery coming through, then you'll probably get a period when there's less talk of delay."
The mark firmed against the Italian lira to 997.05/25 lire by 1625 GMT from late Tuesday's European level of 995.15/45. Dealers said earlier that the Bank of Italy had checked prices.
The central bank checked mark/lira prices at around 996 lire per mark, but did not deal, traders said. At that time, the cross stood at around 995.70.
The French franc softened slightly to 3.3733/38 per mark from yesterday's close of 3.3712/15, while the peseta eased to 84.83/86 from 84.75.
Nordic currencies made mild gains during the session but most had rowed back to near previous European closing levels by late session.
